Art. 4.26. 
Close relatives, possibly in concurrence with the father and mother 
If the deceased has left no descendants, his close relatives, possibly in concurrence with his father and mother, are called to the succession in accordance with the rules set out in the following paragraphs.
 If the deceased leaves, in the case provided for in paragraph 1, a surviving spouse, the rights of the close relatives and, where applicable, those of his father and mother, are however limited to the bare ownership of the other assets of the deceased's own patrimony as defined in Article 4.17, ¤ 2, 2¡.
 Where the father and mother of a person who has died without issue have survived him, and he has left brothers, sisters or their descendants, the succession is divided into two equal portions, one half of which is referred to the father and mother, who share it equally between them. The other half goes to the next of kin.
Where only the father or mother of the person who died without issue is predeceased, the portion that would have devolved to them in accordance with paragraph 3 is combined with the half devolved to the close relatives.
In the event of the predecease of both the father and the mother of a person who dies without issue, the close relatives are called to the succession, to the exclusion of other ascendants and other relatives.
